Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Geometric Unified Learning
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is that the proposed Geometric Unified Learning (GUL) technology, consisting of reusable building blocks, overcomes several disadvantages of deep learning methods and brings increased value to end-users by: 1) saving time and resources in data processing, since GUL has an auto data cleaning and compressing capability; 2) fitting data before it is input to a deep neural network to avoid overfitting since GUL can search and learn simultaneously and select the most important data to use; 3) providing transparency and trustworthy solutions that can easily be understood by data-to-decision makers; 4) making data analysis interesting for software developers, scientists and engineers outside of the machine learning field since GUL outputs are comprehensible; 5) producing flexible, robust and agile solutions for debugging since GULâ€™s components can be decomposed or re-organized to form new solutions for different problems; and 6) saving money since GUL runs faster in parallel and only uses around 1% of the original data points.<br/><br/>This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project has several intellectual merits that address several technical challenges in deep learning, such as garbage-in producing garbage-out, needing large volumes of training data, long running times, unexplainable outputs, excessive parameter tuning, then repeating until the desired results are obtained. GUL, rooted in differential geometry, creates appropriate local (GUL) coordinate systems, Riemannian (GUL) metrics, transformations, and geodesics to identify data invariants, intrinsic patterns to engineer and design GUL data adaptors, characteristic extractors, and measurements that can be reinforced to be better each time an end-user runs their data. The GUL tools have capabilities of vectorizing data, compressing data, searching and learning simultaneously, with highly interpretable results. When the technology makes predictions it will show the user exactly which data points are responsible for those predictions.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Geometric Unified Learning (GUL) is a game-changing breakthrough in explainable machine learning technology for data-to-decision (dasion, the name of the company), offering unrivaled speed and accuracy that surpasses deep learning methods. By leveraging its strengths and addressing the black-box challenges in data-to-decision processes, GUL has the potential to revolutionize financial and disease diagnostics and treatment decisions across industries.

 

GUL's astounding capabilities include 99.5% accurate stroke detection using a 10-second video clip, over 90% accuracy in samuidentifying Alzheimer's, autism, depression, and Parkinson's from just 30 seconds of voice data, and 100% accurate mild traumatic brain injury (TBI) detection using only 20 minutes of EEG data. This enables real-time TBI diagnosis for soldiers, gamers, construction workers, infants, students, and vehicle accident victims worldwide.

 

Rooted in differential geometry, GUL technology comprises reusable building blocks that tackle numerous deep learning challenges such as garbage-in producing garbage-out, large training data requirements, lengthy run times, unexplainable outputs, and excessive parameter tuning. By developing suitable local coordinate systems, Riemannian metrics, transformers, and geodesics, GUL pinpoints data invariants, biomarkers, and intrinsic patterns, engineering data adaptors, characteristic extractors, and measurements.

 

With the support of NSF and the I-Corps program, Dasion has made significant strides in commercializing GUL technology. 

 

First, despite the prevalence of AI/ML in medicine, its unexplainability has hindered healthcare adoption. GUL breaks through this barrier, but clinical trials and FDA approvals require considerable time and investment. As a solution, Dasion partners with companies already in clinical trials that use GUL APIs to enhance prediction results, with some contracts already signed.

 

Second, GUL's robust mathematical foundation enables widespread medical applications, attracting interest from CEOs, CIOs, CMOs, and clinicians. Following initial meetings, contracts were signed with various organizations. Dasion plans to establish marketing and product teams in Phase 2 to disseminate GUL methodology throughout the USA and globally.

 

Third, Dasion focuses on voice and EEG pathways due to their noninvasive, cost-effective, and efficient qualities. Dasion conducted extensive research including on mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI) and found that GUL requires significantly less data and yields higher accuracy than deep learning methods. GUL technology is US patent-pending, with FDA approval in progress.

 

Fourth, Dasion's focus on GUL EEG technology revealed numerous applications, including diagnosis/screening, drug development, neuromarketing, daily health, metaverse, and age/disability assistance. Open medical datasets using EEG facilitate data-driven research, leading to advancements in patient care and a new EEG market ecosystem driven by machine learning. Dasion organized these findings in two papers invited for publication.

 

GUL technology has numerous broader impacts, such as:

 

  1. Minimizing physician burnout and misdiagnosis rates
  2. Saving time and resources with auto data cleaning and compression capabilities.
  3. Reducing overfitting and GUL can search and learn simultaneously, selecting the most crucial data to use.
  4. Providing transparent, trustworthy solutions easily understood by data-to-decision makers.
  5. Making data analysis interesting for software developers, scientists, and engineers outside the machine learning field, as GUL outputs are comprehensible.
  6. Training advanced high school, college, and graduate students to use GUL, producing a new workforce (Dasion trained 35 students through its intern program).
  7. Serving as an inspiring role model for females and minorities through the experiences of PI, Dr. Weiqing Gu, a multidisciplinary female minority with master's and PhD degrees in mathematics, and an additional master's degree in computer science. As someone who taught linear algebra, multiV-calculus, and probability in college at the young age of 18, Dr. Gu exemplifies the capabilities of women in mathematics and computer science, empowering others to pursue their passions in these fields.
  8. Producing flexible, robust, and agile solutions for debugging, as GUL's components can be decomposed or reorganized to form new solutions for different problems.
  9. Saving money, as GUL runs faster in parallel and only uses around 1% of the original data points.
  10. Revolutionizing real-time diagnosis and screening by utilizing GUL's patient-centric approach, ability of capturing characteristics and patterns of a disease. This enables GUL-based applications to run on everyday devices like smartphones and personal computers, making accurate, on-the-spot diagnostics more accessible than ever before.
  11. Safeguarding patient privacy by ensuring that GUL methods do not require extracting patient data from hospitals for training GUL models. GUL tools will improve with each use while maintaining the security and confidentiality of patients' information.

 

In conclusion, the NSF SBIR Phase I project has successfully led to the development of the groundbreaking GUL technology, boasting significant intellectual merit and broader impacts. As a trailblazing innovation, GUL is set to redefine the landscape of machine learning technology and revolutionize the way we approach diagnostics and decision-making across a multitude of domains. The enthusiasm and dedication of the Dasion team, coupled with the immense business opportunities and potential for global impact, make GUL an essential player in the future of machine learning and real-world applications.

  • Dasion chose to focus on voice (>90 accuracy) and EEG pathways due to their minimally invasive, cost-effective, and efficient nature. GUL requires only 20 minutes of data from one or two EEG channels to achieve 99% accuracy, compared to deep learning's 76% accuracy using hours of data -19 channels.

    Dasion's smaple products help your organization overcome ML challenges - NSF Award 2036493.

By leveraging its strengths and addressing the black-box challenges in data-to-decision processes, GUL has the potential to revolutionize financial and disease diagnostics and treatment decisions across industries. GUL's astounding capabilities include 99.5% accurate stroke detection using a 10-second video clip, over 90% accuracy in samuidentifying Alzheimer's, autism, depression, and Parkinson's from just 30 seconds of voice data, and 100% accurate mild traumatic brain injury (TBI) detection using only 20 minutes of EEG data. This enables real-time TBI diagnosis for soldiers, gamers, construction workers, infants, students, and vehicle accident victims worldwide. Rooted in differential geometry, GUL technology comprises reusable building blocks that tackle numerous deep learning challenges such as garbage-in producing garbage-out, large training data requirements, lengthy run times, unexplainable outputs, and excessive parameter tuning. By developing suitable local coordinate systems, Riemannian metrics, transformers, and geodesics, GUL pinpoints data invariants, biomarkers, and intrinsic patterns, engineering data adaptors, characteristic extractors, and measurements. With the support of NSF and the I-Corps program, Dasion has made significant strides in commercializing GUL technology. First, despite the prevalence of AI/ML in medicine, its unexplainability has hindered healthcare adoption. GUL breaks through this barrier, but clinical trials and FDA approvals require considerable time and investment. Following initial meetings, contracts were signed with various organizations. Dasion plans to establish marketing and product teams in Phase 2 to disseminate GUL methodology throughout the USA and globally. Third, Dasion focuses on voice and EEG pathways due to their noninvasive, cost-effective, and efficient qualities. Dasion conducted extensive research including on mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI) and found that GUL requires significantly less data and yields higher accuracy than deep learning methods. GUL technology is US patent-pending, with FDA approval in progress. Fourth, Dasion's focus on GUL EEG technology revealed numerous applications, including diagnosis/screening, drug development, neuromarketing, daily health, metaverse, and age/disability assistance. Open medical datasets using EEG facilitate data-driven research, leading to advancements in patient care and a new EEG market ecosystem driven by machine learning. Dasion organized these findings in two papers invited for publication. GUL technology has numerous broader impacts, such as: Minimizing physician burnout and misdiagnosis rates Saving time and resources with auto data cleaning and compression capabilities. Reducing overfitting and GUL can search and learn simultaneously, selecting the most crucial data to use. Providing transparent, trustworthy solutions easily understood by data-to-decision makers. Making data analysis interesting for software developers, scientists, and engineers outside the machine learning field, as GUL outputs are comprehensible. Training advanced high school, college, and graduate students to use GUL, producing a new workforce (Dasion trained 35 students through its intern program). Serving as an inspiring role model for females and minorities through the experiences of PI, Dr. Weiqing Gu, a multidisciplinary female minority with master's and PhD degrees in mathematics, and an additional master's degree in computer science. As someone who taught linear algebra, multiV-calculus, and probability in college at the young age of 18, Dr. Gu exemplifies the capabilities of women in mathematics and computer science, empowering others to pursue their passions in these fields. Producing flexible, robust, and agile solutions for debugging, as GUL's components can be decomposed or reorganized to form new solutions for different problems. Saving money, as GUL runs faster in parallel and only uses around 1% of the original data points. Revolutionizing real-time diagnosis and screening by utilizing GUL's patient-centric approach, ability of capturing characteristics and patterns of a disease. This enables GUL-based applications to run on everyday devices like smartphones and personal computers, making accurate, on-the-spot diagnostics more accessible than ever before. Safeguarding patient privacy by ensuring that GUL methods do not require extracting patient data from hospitals for training GUL models. GUL tools will improve with each use while maintaining the security and confidentiality of patients' information. In conclusion, the NSF SBIR Phase I project has successfully led to the development of the groundbreaking GUL technology, boasting significant intellectual merit and broader impacts. As a trailblazing innovation, GUL is set to redefine the landscape of machine learning technology and revolutionize the way we approach diagnostics and decision-making across a multitude of domains. The enthusiasm and dedication of the Dasion team, coupled with the immense business opportunities and potential for global impact, make GUL an essential player in the future of machine learning and real-world applications.
